description: Explore cosmic chemistry, molecular spectroscopy, and prebiotic molecules in space

slides.title: Welcome to Astrochemistry
slides.content:
# Introduction to Astrochemistry

Welcome to **Astrochemistry** - chemistry in the cosmos!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Cosmic Abundances** - Element distribution
- **Molecular Spectroscopy** - Detecting molecules
- **Interstellar Medium** - Chemistry in space
- **Prebiotic Molecules** - Origins of life
- **Planetary Chemistry** - Atmospheres and surfaces

> **Fun Fact:** Over 200 different molecules have been detected in space!

slides.title: Cosmic Abundances
slides.content:
# Cosmic Element Abundances

## Big Bang Elements:
- Hydrogen: 75% (by mass)
- Helium: 24%
- Lithium: Trace

## Stellar Nucleosynthesis:
| Process | Elements Made |
|---------|---------------|
| H fusion | Helium |
| He fusion | Carbon, Oxygen |
| Further fusion | Up to Iron |
| Supernovae | Heavier elements |

## Cosmic Abundances:
1. Hydrogen (most)
2. Helium
3. Oxygen
4. Carbon
5. Neon
6. Iron

slides.title: Spectroscopy Basics
slides.content:
# Spectroscopy in Astronomy

## Types:

| Type | What It Reveals |
|------|----------------|
| Absorption | Atoms absorbing light |
| Emission | Atoms emitting light |
| Molecular | Molecule signatures |
| Rotational | Molecule rotation |
| Vibrational | Molecule vibration |

## Doppler Effect:
- Blueshift: Moving toward us
- Redshift: Moving away
- Gives velocity information

## Line Profiles:
- Width indicates temperature
- Strength indicates abundance

slides.title: The Interstellar Medium
slides.content:
# The Interstellar Medium (ISM)

## Components:
- Gas (99%)
- Dust (1%)

## Phases of ISM:

| Phase | Temperature | Density |
|-------|------------|--------|
| Hot ionized | 10^6 K | Very low |
| Warm ionized | 8000 K | Low |
| Warm neutral | 8000 K | Low |
| Cold neutral | 100 K | Medium |
| Molecular clouds | 10-20 K | High |

## Molecular Clouds:
- Giant molecular clouds
- Sites of star formation
- Rich chemistry

slides.title: Molecules in Space
slides.content:
# Molecules Detected in Space

## Simple Molecules:
- H2 (hydrogen)
- CO (carbon monoxide)
- H2O (water)
- NH3 (ammonia)
- CH4 (methane)

## Complex Molecules:
- Methanol (CH3OH)
- Formaldehyde (H2CO)
- Formic acid (HCOOH)
- Ethanol (C2H5OH)

## PAHs:
- Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons
- Common in ISM
- May relate to life's origins

## Detection Methods:
- Radio telescopes
- Infrared spectroscopy
- Submillimeter astronomy

slides.title: Dust Grains
slides.content:
# Interstellar Dust

## Composition:
- Silicates (rocky)
- Carbonaceous (carbon-rich)
- Ice mantles (water, CO, CO2)

## Size:
- Sub-micron to microns
- Comparable to smoke particles

## Effects:
- Extinction (dimming light)
- Reddening (scatters blue)
- Infrared emission

## Importance:
- Sites for molecule formation
- H2 forms on grain surfaces
- Seed material for planets

slides.title: Chemical Reactions in Space
slides.content:
# Chemical Reactions in Space

## Gas Phase:
- Ion-molecule reactions (fast)
- Neutral-neutral (slow at low T)
- Photodissociation (UV breaks bonds)

## Grain Surface:
- Atoms land on grains
- Migrate and react
- H2 forms this way

## Key Reactions:
```
H + H (on grain) -> H2
C+ + OH -> CO + H+
H3+ + CO -> HCO+ + H2
```

## Timescales:
- Chemistry is slow (millions of years)
- Matches cloud lifetimes

slides.title: Prebiotic Chemistry
slides.content:
# Prebiotic Molecules in Space

## Building Blocks of Life:
- Amino acids (in meteorites)
- Sugars (glycolaldehyde detected)
- Nucleobases (possibly)

## Interesting Detections:
- Glycine (simplest amino acid) - debated
- Glycolaldehyde (sugar)
- Methyl isocyanate (peptide bonds)

## Implications:
- Life's chemistry not unique to Earth
- Delivered by meteorites/comets
- Panspermia hypothesis

## Murchison Meteorite:
- Fell in 1969
- Over 70 amino acids
- Both L and D forms

slides.title: Planetary Atmospheres
slides.content:
# Atmospheric Chemistry

## Terrestrial Planets:

| Planet | Main gases |
|--------|------------|
| Venus | CO2, N2, H2SO4 clouds |
| Earth | N2, O2 |
| Mars | CO2, thin |

## Giant Planets:
- H2, He dominated
- CH4, NH3, H2O clouds

## Titan:
- N2, CH4 atmosphere
- Methane cycle (like water on Earth)
- Complex organic chemistry

## Photochemistry:
- UV drives reactions
- Creates hazes, smog

slides.title: Hot Jupiters and Exoplanet Atmospheres
slides.content:
# Exoplanet Atmospheric Chemistry

## Detection Methods:
- Transit spectroscopy
- Eclipse spectroscopy
- Direct imaging

## Detected Species:
- H2O (water vapor)
- CO, CO2
- Na, K (alkali metals)
- CH4 (methane)

## Hot Jupiters:
- Close to stars
- Very hot (>1000 K)
- Strange chemistry

## Biosignatures:
- O2 + CH4 together
- O3 (ozone)
- Unusual combinations

slides.title: Comets and Asteroids
slides.content:
# Comets and Asteroids Chemistry

## Comets:
- "Dirty snowballs"
- Water ice, CO, CO2, CH4
- Dust with organic material
- Pristine solar system material

## Comet Composition:
- H2O: 80-90% of ice
- CO: 1-20%
- CO2: 2-6%
- Complex organics

## Asteroids:
- Carbonaceous: Organic-rich
- Silicate: Rocky
- Metallic: Iron-nickel

## Delivered to Earth:
- Water (possibly)
- Organic molecules
- Amino acids

slides.title: Astrochemistry Tools
slides.content:
# Tools of Astrochemistry

## Space Telescopes:
- James Webb Space Telescope (infrared)
- Hubble (UV, visible)
- Herschel (far-infrared)

## Radio Telescopes:
- ALMA (millimeter/submillimeter)
- VLA, NOEMA
- Detect rotational transitions

## Laboratory Work:
- Measure spectra
- Simulate space conditions
- Reaction rates

## Computer Models:
- Chemical networks
- Thousands of reactions
- Predict abundances

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Astrochemistry Summary

## Cosmic abundances:
- H dominant, then He, O, C
- Heavy elements from stars

## Interstellar Medium:
- Phases from hot ionized to cold molecular
- 200+ molecules detected

## Key Chemistry:
- Gas phase and grain surface
- Long timescales

## Prebiotic Molecules:
- Amino acids in meteorites
- Space delivers building blocks

## Atmospheric Chemistry:
- Each world unique
- Biosignature searches

> **Congratulations!** You've completed Astrochemistry!
